authors.name: Hannah   Safford
authors.affiliation: Mel Johnson [UC Davis], Heather Bischel [UC Davis]

description:
{"blocks":[{"key":"devl9","text":"Flow virometry can support advanced water treatment and reuse by delivering near real-time information about viral water quality. Realizing the full potential of this technique, requires rigorous sample-preparation protocols as well as objective, automated methods for expediting and improving FVM data analysis. Below, we present an optimized sample-preparation protocol for FVM-based detection and enumeration of T4 bacteriophage, an environmentally relevant viral surrogate. The protocol, which was rigorously optimized using a fractional factorial experimental design, blends and improves on existing protocols developed using a traditional “pipeline”-style optimization approach. As use of FVM for viral water-quality assessment expands, we recommend that this protocol be used to validate instrument performance prior to and alongside application of FVM on environmental samples. Widespread adoption of a consistent, optimized analytical approach will engender confidence in FVM data and will facilitate cross-laboratory comparisons.


","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: flow cytometry, flow virometry, T4, bacteriophage

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

{"blocks":[{"key":"a8d1","text":"Add  glutaraladehyde to the sample at a final concentration of   and incubate at    for  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":63,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":81,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":88,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7op1u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c01t7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bn93t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"0.5","error_concentration":false,"guid":"1CC81520C7B711EC92F1D343026D5985","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":14}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"4139C390C7B711EC92F1D343026D5985","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"2":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":900,"guid":"45CA6F40C7B711EC92F1D343026D5985","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":57}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f2cks","text":"Diluted, glutaraldehyde-treated samples may be stored at   prior to analysis. Avoid repeated freeze-thaw cycles to avoid compromising sample integrity.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"au82r","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"563DDC40C7B711EC92F1D343026D5985","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-80","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8chhj","text":"Stain the sample. Add either SYBR Green I or SYBR Gold (depending on whether the species of interest include both DNA and RNA viruses) to the glutaraldehyde-treated sample at 5 x 10-5 sample volume and incubate in the dark at   for at least   .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":181,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":226,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":241,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7emne","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e0rp4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2v3e1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A35B6060C7B711EC92F1D343026D5985","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"50","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":60,"guid":"AC0A9500C7B711EC92F1D343026D5985","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cro7n","text":"Sample should be analyzed as soon as possible after the staining is complete.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1f75a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"huc6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"at910","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8lra8","text":"The staining protocol explicated above is designed to be compatible with sample analysis via FVM on a wide variety of flow cytometers. Below, we provide settings for sample analysis on a NovoCyte 2070V coupled with a NovoSampler Pro autosampler (Agilent). In adapting these settings to other instrumentation, the key components to retain are (1) a slow flow rate, and (2) rinses in between each sample to thoroughly flush the fluidics.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cvmod","text":"Settings for sample analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3stj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bsvj0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4m9gj","text":"Collect data using the 488 nm (blue) laser as well as the FSC, SSC, and FITC (530 ± 30 nm) lasers. Analyze a 10-mL volume of each sample was using the lowest instrument flowrate (5 mL/min) and a FITC = 800 threshold. The analysis may be performed with or without instrument mixing of the sample prior to analysis.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d8oiv","text":"Settings for rinses.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7dfop","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"38lds","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e46mn","text":"Flush fluidics in between each sample by running 150 mL of 1x NovoClean solution (Agilent) followed by 150 mL of MQ water through the sample intake port (SIP) at the highest instrument flowrate (120 mL/min).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
